Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Orchestrating transcriptional reprogramming by combinatorial complexity of general transcriptional regulation and specific immune responses
Award.AbstractNarration: Perception of evolutionarily conserved microbial components elicits robust plant immune responses, including rapid and profound transcriptional reprogramming against pathogen attack. The signaling networks underlying plant immunity remain largely elusive. We have developed a sensitive genetic screen based on the early transcriptional changes upon pathogen signal perception. This high-throughput screen was grounded in Arabidopsis transgenic plants carrying an early and specific immune responsive marker gene FRK1 promoter fused with a luciferase (LUC) reporter. A series of mutants with altered pFRK1::LUC activity were identified from an EMS-mutagenized population and named as Arabidopsis genes governing immune gene expression (aggie). These aggie mutants exhibited distinct patterns of altered immune responses, suggesting that the mutations likely occur at different genes/pathways in plant immune signaling. Molecular cloning and biochemical characterization of these Aggie genes hold significant promise to reveal novel components in plant immune signaling and uncover mechanisms by which specific immune responsive gene expression is regulated by the general transcriptional machinery. The project will elucidate the signaling networks underlying plant immunity and provide enriched genetic resources for manipulation of crops with broad-spectrum and durable resistance. Our aggie-luc screen was specifically tailored for undergraduate students, and will provide training for graduate and postdoctoral researchers. The project includes an innovative and comprehensive education and outreach program centering on Green Immunology with seminars, lectures and cutting-edge research experiences for high school and undergraduate students, particularly underrepresented minority students in the Texas Rio Grande Valley.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project is to elucidate the signaling networks underlying plant immunity with a genetic screen based on the early transcriptional changes upon pathogen perception. The research supported by this grant has unraveled multifaceted signaling mechanisms of plant immunity and established a new paradigm for understanding plant immune signaling. We have identified various novel components and elucidated previously unrecognized mechanisms in plant immunity. In particular, we demonstrated that immune gene transcription is regulated by phosphorylation dynamics of RNA polymerase II (Cell Host & Microbe, 2014; 2016), and identified a novel trihelix transcription factor ASR3 that negatively regulates immune gene expression (Plant Cell, 2015). We elucidated that protein poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation (PARylation) plays an essential role in immune gene regulation and plant defense, and identified the first plant PARylation target (PLoS Genetics, 2015; EMBO Reports, 2016; PLoS Pathogens, 2016). We further extended the luciferase-based genetic screen to understand plant effector-triggered immunity and identified the malectin domain RLKs ANXs as a molecular link of two-tiered plant immunity (Plant Cell, 2017). So far, related to this project, we have published 16 peer-reviewed research articles, nine peer-reviewed review articles, and one book chapter, and edited the book “Plant Pattern Recognition Receptor Methods and Protocols” in Methods in Molecular Biology, which serves as a laboratory manual for plant immunity community.  Broader Impact: This project termed AGGIE-LUC screen was specifically tailored for undergraduates. The first set of screens was led by a REU student. We have hosted ~70 undergraduate and high school students for research experience with more than half are Hispanic or African American. Two of them were awarded ASPB SURF program. We have integrated this research project into a minority student outreach and education program partnered with Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), organized annual Green Immunology workshop, and recruited HSI students to Ph.D programs. In addition, we have trained seven postdoctoral researchers (five now are faculty in various universities), seven graduate students (four graduated and three current) and six visiting scholars. The data from this support have been published in scientific journals, deposited in NCBI, or stored in PI’s laboratory or servers. All published DNA constructs and seeds have been freely available to the researchers in the non-profit organizations.
